item.title: Eye Heart Eyes
item.description: Wearing masks have really focused my attention on the diversity, expressiveness, and beauty of eyes. I kind of get why artists and poets are so obsessed with them. (However, I’ve learned from experience that it’s typically an oddball thing to compliment strangers on. üòÇ I’m typically really free about saying “I love your hair!” or “Nice tattoo, man!” to random people. But complimenting people’s eyes usually comes across as flirting, or as being on drugs or something.

item.title: Phone-y Bologna
item.description: Me: “Where does all my time go? How am I supposed to get anything done? When’s the last time I even ate?” Also Me: Spends an hour on the phone with his friend in India Spends fourty-five minutes on the phone with his friend living three blocks away Spends an hour and a half on the phone with his best friend’s mom Spends an hour and a half on the phone with his former boss

item.title: Boxer Shorts
item.description: Very random fun fact–in India, it is customary for men to wear a second pair of underwear underneath their boxers. Which turns them into acceptable loungewear and marginally acceptable attire for a very casual motorcycle ride down to the market.

item.title: Wisdom
item.description: Me: Oh, this really long elaborate GitHub issue I wrote two years ago is overcomplicating this. I can do a much simpler thing! Let me just do that. Me: (spends time doing simple thing) Me: WAIT AHHHHH Me: NO THIS DOES NOT WORK WHY DID I NOT TRUST 2016 ME WHO OBVIOUSLY THOUGHT THIS THROUGH DAMN IT

item.title: Maratha Blues
item.description: #1 on the list of things I don’t appreciate about Maharastra: How I kind of like the taste of raw onions after living here. This is NOT good for your love lives, guys, just remember that.

item.title: Do-uble Entendre
item.description: I was on an online forum discussing some of India’s greatest unsolved mysteries, and someone wrote “One of the unsolved mysteries is that someone stole my self esteem and I can’t get it back.” Until I read someone’s response (“Bhai Tinder uninstall kar do, self respect wapas aa jayegi”), I somehow parsed the poster as saying that his car (a Maruti Esteem) had been stolen. I should have been tipped off by the idea that someone had stolen that model of car, if nothing else.

item.title: Reunion
Bajaranji Bakvaas
Cultural Exchange
Mysterious Ways
item.description: Brains work in, uh, mysterious ways. Today, I observed the weirdest instance of mine getting its “wires crossed”. In lieu of change, a salesclerk gave me a couple pieces of expresso candy. My intention afterwards was to eat a piece of candy and simultaneously start a work task. I sat down and popped the candy in my mouth, all according to plan. But suddenly, I felt a surge of alarm, convinced for a split-second that I had somehow eaten the task I was intending to complete.

item.title: Karthick Bhee Hain
Meh Americano Samajatha Hoon
Pani Hai
item.description: On my daily commute home, I was carrying some rum to share for a birthday party in our P.G. After my bag went through the scanner at the metro station and I retrieved it, the female guard ran after me and indicated I needed to talk to the analyst about something he saw on the scanner. Analyst: “Water bottle?” Isaac: “Nei nei. Um…” (Unzips bag to show contents) Analyst (smiling as he examines the rum bottle): “Water bottle hai.

item.title: Faux Maturity
item.description: Symptoms of faux maturity: Avoiding things you’d find fun because they are not what an “adult” does. (E.g. Dyeing your hair purple, playing video games.) Doing things you hate because they ARE what an “adult” does. (Buying a house, tending to a lawn, smoking, drinking coffee or alcohol.) Shaming or thinking less of people for doing harmless but weird or non-age-typical things. (Scoffing at someone for watching cartoons or putting M&Ms on their pizza.

item.title: Anthropological Anxiety
item.description: Isaac’s mandatory mental checklist whilst hanging out with his (majority desi / south asian) friends: Make an extremely convoluted conclusion about desi culture. What observations cause you to draw this conclusion? What assumptions are supporting the way you notice and interpret those actions? In what scenarios could those assumptions possibly be legitimate or illegitimate, and is that even a clearly defined boundary? Am I overthinking this? I‚Äôm overthinking this. This is not how a normal person hangs out with their friends.

item.title: It's called shoestring travelling, and there's a SUBREDDIT, thank you
item.description: Isaac: “It’s completely possible to travel in India for less than $200 a month. You just have to be willing to give up all pretense of safety and comfort. Mostly, just be gregarious with people you meet in general and even on the street - they’ll invite you to stay with them, and your travels will totally be enriched.” Boss (exasperated, horrified): “Isaac, where were your parents?”

item.title: Feline Fiction
item.description: Despite rather badly wanting a dog, I’m not sure enough about my lifestyle in the next decade or even five years or so to actually take the leap and buy/adopt one. Therefore, I’ve attached myself to two very affectionate local cats that belong to my neighbors, who allow them to walk outside freely most days. I’ve talked briefly to the owners and gotten the cats' names–Mr. and Mrs. Bunny, and their adopted son Bunny Jr.
